guideline.name: Annotation of PRO Guideline for capecitabine,fluorouracil and DPYD

literature.title: Pharmacogenetics of anti-cancer drugs: State of the art and implementation - recommendations of the French National Network of Pharmacogenetics.

summaryMarkdown.html: The French National Network of Pharmacogenetics (Réseau national de pharmacogénétique (RNPGx)) recommends testing for DPYD deficiency before initiating a treatment regimen based on 5-FU or capecitabine, with dose reductions for DPYD partial deficiency and contraindicates fluoropyrimidines in patients with complete deficiency.

textMarkdown.html:
The French National Network of Pharmacogenetics (RNPGx) publication about the state of the art and clinical implementation — recommendations from the French National Network of Pharmacogenetics for anti-cancer drugs states:

The RNPGx recommends screening for DPYD deficiency before initiating a treatment regimen based on 5-FU or capecitabine, especially in patients at risk of toxicity (protocols using bolus administration or high-doses, fluoropyrimidine toxicity reported in a family member) or in an adjuvant situation.

Phenotyping by determining the serum UH2/U ratio or lymphocyte DPD activity is considered essential

If phenotyping is not available, genotyping should be performed... genotyping to search for the three consensual variants as proposed by the CPIC (*2A rs3918290, *13 rs55886062, and c.2846A>T rs67376798) is advisable.

If genotyping predicts partial deficiency (patient who is heterozygous for one of the alleles *2A, *13, or c.2846A>T), dose should be reduced 50% for the first cycle. If a complete deficiency is demonstrated, fluoropyrimidines are contraindicated due to the risk of fatal toxicity with the standard dose.

While the recommendation section text does not mention Hap3B rs56038477 it is listed in Table 1 and in Table 3 the diplotype *1/HapB3 is given activity score of 1.5 and 75% of standard dose.
